p.note: Aaron of Serugh was a disciple of Mar Awginand founder of two monasteries near Melitene.

In hagiography: Abai was a Persian Martyr killed by his father,Adorpirozgerd, who later converted to Christianity. He was mentioned in the legend ofSaba Pirgushnasp. He was martyred with his motherAstina (Hwarta)and 5000 friends.
Abā was a Bishop ofNinevehwho was martyred under shah Shapur II.
In hagiography: Abai ofḤaḥwas a monk, miracle-worker, and disciple ofSimeon of Qartmin. He became abbot ofQartminand helped to end a plague through his prayers.
In hagiography: ʿAbda was a bishop ofEdessa.
ʿAbdā was Bishop ofHormizd Ardashirwho was martyred during the reign of Yazdegerd I withAfrēm, Jacob,Papa, anotherPapa,Daduq, andDurtanthe learned.
Afrēm was a Persian Martyr and scribe martyred under shah Yazdegerd with companions'Abda, Jacob, Papa the deacon, Daduq and Durtan the learned.

ʿAbdā Alaha, priest, was tortured withʿAbdishōʿby Ardashir, brother of Sapor; ʿAbdā was arrested with seven friends and seven virgins. Barḥaḏbshabā and Samuel also were executed. Then ʿAbdishōʿ and ʿAbdā Alaha were executed. They were buried by Byzantine slaves in a neighboring village. He was martyred with 38 companions.

ʿAbdishōʿ ofKashkarwas tortured with the priestʿAbdā Alahaby Ardashir, brother of Sapor; ʿAbdā was arrested with seven friends and seven virgins. Barḥaḏbshabā and Samuel also were executed. Then ʿAbdishōʿ and ʿAbdā Alaha were executed. They were buried by Byzantine slaves in a neighboring village. He was martyred with 38 companions.
In hagiography: ʿAbdachisia was a martyr from Aphrodisias inCaria.

ʿAbdelmasiḥ was a Jewish shepherd boy (formally known as Aser) who lived nearSinjarin the Persian Empire. He converted to Christianity and pierced his ear to put on an earring, apparently the sign of slavery. He was martyred by his father.

In hagiography: ʿAbdon and Sennen were two Persian twins martyred inRome. Their story was contained in the martyrology ofBishop Polychrone, a bishop of Babylon. They do not figure in Syriac hagiography, but in the Latin tradition they are calledCiccensis adiabenicis victis.

In hagiography: Abel was the first stylite saint of the monastery ofQartminand was a patron against eye disease and paralysis. According to hagiographic tradition,Philoxenus of Mabbugcalled upon him for a benediction.
Abḥay features inJohn of Ephesus'Lives of the Eastern Saints. He was an ascetic who was ordained Bishop of Nicaea and later became founder of the Monastery of the Oaks.
In hagiography: Abimelech was a theologian of theSchool of Baladwho became founder of themartyrion, a secondary institution of theSchool of Nisibis.
In hagiography: Abraham is a monk of undertmined origins, possibly from the convent ofBeth ʿArbin.
Abraham was a Bishop ofArbelawho was martyred under Shapur II.

Abraham was a famous monk and miracle-worker of the monastery of the High Mountain north ofMount Izla, and he was the teacher of Bar Ṣauma. He founded a monastery nearMidyatwhere the stylite Abel was.
Abraham was a Persian martyr and layman who was stoned under the orders of shah Shapur II.
In hagiography: Abraham the Penitent (or ofBeth Sayyare) was a monk from the family ofAwginandAbraham the Great. He founded a monastery atZāwīṯā, west ofBamarne.
In hagiography: Abraham the Scribe, also known as Abraham ofShawur, was a monk ofQartminwho cured lepers.
Abraham Qidūnāyā was an anchorite whose niece, Mary, fell from the ascetic life but was redeemed through his love.
According toThe Teaching of Addai, Abshelama (or Barshelama) was an early bishop ofEdessaand a copyist for the apostleAddai.

In hagiography: Acyndinus, Anempodistus , Pegasius, Aphtonius, and Elpidiphorus were Greek Christians who died during the reign of Shapur II, according to the legendary Acts describing their martyrdom.
Aday Khurʾepesqupa was a monk and chorepiscopus commemorated in John of Ephesus' Lives of the Eastern Saints.
Aday was commemorated byJohn of Ephesusin his Lives of the Eastern Saints. He built twelve monasteries with his brotherAbraham.

Addai (Aday) was one of the 72 apostles commissioned by Jesus to be a missionary. Aday was ordained byThomasto travel toEdessa, and he cured King Abgar's foot. The conversion of Edessa was attributed to his missionary activity and described in the Teaching of Addai.

Adorhormizd (later "Dadisho") was a high-born mobed who converted to Christianity after his daughter,Anahid, was healed through the work of Christian monk, Pethion. Both he and Anahid became Christian martyrs.
In hagiography: Adorparma was a martyr of Tur Berʿain inBeth Garmaiwho was commemorated with his brother Mirnarsai and sister Sultana Mahduht.
According toThe Teaching of Addai, Aggai was ordained byAddaito be a bishop ofEdessa; he was martyred by the son of King Abgar.
Mar Aḥā was the Bishop ofArzunand a Miaphysite missionary saint among the Armenians.
Aḥa the Egyptian was a monk and disciple of MarAwginhead of Awgin's spiritual phalanx, who came with him fromEgyptand constructed a monastery east of Tigris in Qardu:Zarnuqa.

In hagiography: Aḥa the solitary of Resh ʿAyna was a soldier in the Persian army; later he founded a monastery nearNisibis, traveled on extensive pilgrimages, and returned with a piece of the true cross. He converted a village of pagan Armenians.
In hagiography: Alphaeus was a martyr ofCaesarea of Palestinewho died during the Diocletian persecution and was commemorated with Zachaeus and Romanus.
In hagiography: Amai was a Persian Martyr from the region ofAdiabene. She was a daughter of the covenant who was killed with other daughters of the covenant, including Thecla.
In hagiography: ʿAmmi ofḤaḥinṬur ʿAbdinbecame the first bishop ofṬur ʿAbdin. He was a disciple ofSimeon of Qartminand martyred in Tanzi.
Anahīd was a high-born Magian princess who converted to Christianity and was martyred. She was healed by the monk Pethion and her conversion led to the conversion of her father,Adorhormizd(Dadisho).
In hagiography: Anastasius the Persian was a soldier in the army of Khusro II. He became a Christian and then a monk after travelling toJerusalem; he was martyred.

In hagiography: Acyndinus, Anempodistus , Pegasius, Aphtonius, and Elpidiphorus were Greek Christians who died during the reign of shah Shapur II, according to the legendary Acts describing their martyrdom.
In hagiography: Anthony the Qurayshite, born Ruhi, was a convert to Christianity from Islam, the nephew of Harun al-Rashid. He was martyred for refusing to return to Islam.

In hagiography: Acyndinus, Anempodistus , Pegasius, Aphtonius, and Elpidiphorus were Greek Christians who died during the reign of shah Shapur II, according to the legendary Acts describing their martyrdom.
In hagiography: Apollonius was a martyr with Eusebonia mentioned by Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: ʿAqewshma was a bishop from the region ofAdiabenewho was martyred during the persecution of Shapur II and buried by an Armenian princess.

In hagiography: Aquilina was a martyr ofByblosand patron of Jbayl. At the age of twelve, she became a Christian missionary, and she converted pagans by her example and teaching. She was martyred by decapitation.
In hagiography: Archelaus was a bishop ofḤarranwho debated withMani.
In hagiography: Athanasius was a monk ofṬur ʿAbdin.
In hagiography: Athanasius the Cameldriver was Patriarch ofAntiochwho benefited from the actions of Emperor Heraclius.
In hagiography: Athanasius was a bishop fromQenneshrin.
In hagiography: Athanasius Sandalaya was the West Syriac Metropolitan ofMaypherqaṭwho constructed a monastery atTel Besmewest ofMardin.
Athqen of Sis came northwards from Iraq to the area of Mount Izla and became the third superior of the monastery of Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: Awdisho was an anchorite monk from the area nearArbelawho converted the soldier-saintQardag.
In hagiography: Awdisho was a bishop and martyr ofKashkar.
In hagiography: Awida was a Persian confessor whose ears and nose were cut off; he had wanted to follow Yasdapnah to martyrdom.

In hagiography: Azad was a deacon of Beth Naggare inAdiabenewho was martyred with the priest Jacob during the persecution of Shapur II. The executioner washed his bloody sword in a pool, and the blood desiccated the pool.
Azād was a eunuch at the court of Shapur II who was martyred a week afterSimeon Bar Sabbaʿeat the gate of the palace of Karka d-Ledan.
In hagiography: Aziza was a monk, born to Egyptian royal pagans, who became a companion ofMar Awginand established a sanctuary in Zerāni, in the district of Gilu orHakkari.
ʿAzāzāʾēl was an illustrious youth from the Orient who travelled toRomeand was martyred under Maximinus.
According to tradition, Babai was a sister ofSharbeland a convert from paganism. She was martyred inEdessain the reign of Trajan.
Bābūlā (Babylas) was a Bishop ofAntiochwho died from poor treatment in prison; he demanded that Emperor Philip the Arab make public penance.
Bākōs (Bacchus) was one of the most popular saints of the Orient. He was a Roman soldier who was martyred shortly before his friendSergiussince he refused to sacrifice to the Roman gods.
Bāday was a priest and Persian Martyr who was flagellated in a garden with pomegranate branches at the command of Mihrnarsai.
Badmā was a high born Zoroastrian and convert to Christianity from Beth Lapat; he was martyred by a treacherous Christian under Shapur II.
In hagiography: Barbara was a pagan girl converted to Christianity and killed by her father after tortures, perhaps during the Diocletian persecution.
Barbaʿshmīn was a Bishop and martyr of Seleucia-Ctesiphon. He was arrested at Karka d-Ledan and martyred during the persecution of Shapur II.
In hagiography Barbʿashmin is commemorated as a Syrian orthodox patriarch.
Barḥaḏbshabā was a deacon of Arbela who was condemned to death during the persecution of Shapur II.
In hagiography: Barhadbeshabba ofQartminwas a monk and disciple ofSamuel of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Barsai was a bishop ofḤarranand thenEdessawhileEphrem the Syrianlived inEdessa; he built the "Grand Baptistery" there.
According to tradition, Barsamyā was an early Bishop of Edessa during the reign of the emperor Trajan and a contemporary with the Edessan martyrsSharbeland Babai.
In hagiography: Barṣawmā was a bishop and martyr of the monastery of Hashrai, presumably inṬur ʿAbdin.

In hagiography: Bar Ŝewya or Bar Shabba was a solitary and first bishop ofMerv; he was deported from Byzantine territory toCtesiphon. The sister or wife of Shapor, Shirawan, became Christian and built a church there which Bar Shabba consecrated.
Barshebyā or Shabbia was a monk who was the superior of a small monastery at Ishtahar, near Persepolis. He was martyred with ten others. His name means "son of the deported."

In hagiography: Bassus and his twin sister Shushān were twin children of a Zoroastrian governor. They were informed about Christianity by a Christian slave. They were baptized by an ascetic named Longinus. They were killed by their father. A monastery was built in their honor near Apamea.

Shushān and her twin brother Bassus were children of a Zoroastrian governor. They were informed about Christianity by a Christian slave. They were baptized by an ascetic namedLonginus. They were killed by their father. A monastery ofMor Bosuswas built in their honor nearApamea.

In hagiography: Mar Bawai was commemorated as the Catholicos of the Church of the East fromTella. He was born a Zoroastrian and converted to Christianity through his encounter with a monk called Mar Abda from Qunni. He became a monk and was elected patriarch. His tenure was marked by the efforts of his rivalBarsaumato "Nestorianize" the Church of the East. Bawai was killed, perhaps because Barsauma had accused him of being an enemy of the Sasanian empire.
In hagiography: Behnam was a son of the covenant fromthe Kirkuk regionwho was stoned under shah Ardashir II.

Behnām and his sisterSarawere high-born Christian martyrs who were the children of Sennacherib. They converted to Christianity through a monk, Mattai, and were killed by their father. Their father later repented and became a Christian and with his wife Queen Shirin. Sennacherib and Shirin built monasteries for Mar Mattai and Abraham nearMosul.
Benyamēn was a deacon and martyr under Vahram V.
In hagiography: Benjamin was a hermit and priest fromDara; he was ordained byBarsai of Edessaand travelled toMount Sinjar. He convertedMaʿin; both Benjamin and Maʿin were martyred.
In hagiography: Benjamin was a disciple ofMar Awgin. He travelled toMount Izlaand founded a monastery and school nearMardin>. His vita may be a version of the life of Mar Miha.
Bīshōy was monk and superior from the Nitrian Egyptian desert whose story was reproduced in Syriac recensions.
In hagiography: Boḥtisho was a deacon and a martyr who assisted Tomarsha in rebuilding churches destroyed under Shapur II. He was martyred under Vahram.
In hagiography: Boḥtizad of Kurke was a saint mentioned in a single East Syriac calendar.
Brīkhīshōʿ and his ten companions were martyred in the time of Shapur; they emerged in the context of a battle.

In hagiography: Briḥisho was the brother ofYawnan. They were two brothers fromBeth Asawho travelled to a neighboring village to encourage more martyrs. According to tradition, they died during the time ofSapor.
In hagiography: Buṭlāna was a doctor and a martyr. His story was a Syriacized version of the life of Pantaleon.
In hagiography: Rabban Buya was a monk who was fromʿAqra; he had many companions and an anonymous sister who was also venerated as a saint. Her tomb was inShaqlawa.

In hagiography: Carpus (Qarpos) was the bishop of Shawaur who was martyred by the Persians; his relics were placed inside a church inṬur ʿAbdinthat was built by Saliba, the father ofSamuel of Qartmin.
Kresṭīnā Yazdūy from Karka d-Beth Slokh was the daughter of a Zoroastrian governor who was martyred after her marriage.

In hagiography: Constantine was a bishop ofLaodicea. He was a friend ofSeverus of Antiochand was present at many of the meetings of the Miaphysites that took place inConstantinople. He was a principal author of thecanons of the Miaphysite communityfrom the sixth century.
In hagiography: Cyprian and Justina were martyrs fromAntiochwho died under the emperor Diocletian.
In hagiography: Cyrus (Qura) was a bishop ofEdessawho transferred the relics ofSt. ThomastoEdessain 394.
Quriyos was a martyr ofḤarranunder Caliph Al Mansur.
In hagiography: Cyrus (Qura) was a superior of themonastery of Qartmin. He was a disciple ofSamuel of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Cyriacus (Quryaqos) was a disciple ofMar Yareth.

In hagiography: Cyriacus was bishop ofAmidaand came from the monastery of Mar Zakka nearEdessa. His church was seized by the Chalcedonians, but he restored his churches under Khusro II. He was the author of 30 ecclesiastical canons.

Cyriacus was a martyr under the Emperor Julian. He was also known as Judas Cyriacus, and he was a convert from Judaism through his mother, Anne. They were martyred together. He was thrown into a pit of snakes.

Cyriacus and his motherJuliettewere martyrs. They were martyred under Diocletian in either Iconium, Tarsus, or Antioch, together with many others. Juliette was martyred with her son of three years of age, Cyriacus.
In hagiography: Mar Dodo (Dada) was a saint fromṬur ʿAbdinand a companion ofMar Awgin. There is a church inBeth Sbirinodedicated to him.
Mar Dōdō was a convert from Zoroastrianism to Christianity. He was condemned to an ordeal of fire. He was martyred under Shapur II.

In hagiography: Damian was patriarch ofAlexandria. He sent a letter toJacob Baradaeushoping for communion between the churches. He visitedAntiochbut broke from the Patriarch of Antioch,Peter of Callinicus, because of the Tritheist controversy. This schism ended with the patriarchate ofAthanasius I Gamolo.

In hagiography: Daniel of the Monastery of the Dung Beetles was a refugee fromAmidaand student ofMar Mattai(his story mirrors the one ofBehnam). He established a monastery near that of his teacher,Mar Mattai, with whom he had fled fromAmida. The monastery he established was called the monastery of the yellow source. There was a miracle of protective beetles connected to this monastery.

In hagiography: Daniel of Galash was a married man who left his wife to become a monk. He met many ascetics in his life, including Mari and Julien Saba. He visited the portrait of Christ inEdessa. He stayed in a cave with Mari, and then he established a monastery on Mount Aysum. His son Lazarus became his disciple. He built a small monastery inRomefor his father.
In hagiography: Daniel was the bishop ofEdessa. He obtained relics ofSeverus of Samosatain order to chase demons away from the monks of the monastery ofQenneshre. He wrote a demonology.
Dānīʾēl (Daniel), a priest, and his sisterWardawere from Raziq, near Tehran. They were arrested two years after BishopMilesof Tel Ḥesh. They were tortured and then decapitated.
Daniel the Doctor was a convert from paganism who travelled to the monastery of Pachomius, then to MarAwginand then Nuhadra. He healed the son of a Persian governor. He lived as a hermit.
In hagiography: Daniel of Qartmin was a monk ofQartminwho was elected bishop ofQartmin.
Daniel of Scete was an Egyptian monk from the sixth century who was venerated in the Syriac tradition.
In hagiography: Daniel the Stylite was a monk and disciple ofSamuel of Qartminwho walked along theTigriswhile he went to the land ofQardu (Gazarta).
In hagiography: David was a saint commemorated on the 25 of September by Rabban Saliba.

In hagiography: David of Ḥarran was the bishop ofḤarran. He was originally a monk fromQartminand a relative ofSimeon of the Olives. He left all of his precious objects to the monastery ofQartmin, including a manuscript containing a collection of canons.

In hagiography: Demetrianus was commemorated as a bishop ofAntioch. He was deported by the Persians after the conquest of the city in 256. The beginnings of the diocese ofGundishapurwere attributed to him.
In hagiography: Denha was a monk of the convent of Qabratha.
In hagiography: Dioscorus was a Patriarch ofAlexandria.
In hagiography: Ten brothers ofQartminare remembered as a group of monks who took part in a fight with villagers fromQartminover the body ofSimeon of Qartmin.
These are three Greek theologians who are commemorated together in the Church of the East: Theodore of Mopsuestia, Diodore of Tarsus, and Nestorius of Constantinople.
Ephrem, Narsai, Abraham, Julian Saba, Jean, Michel, Job, Isaiah, and Bar Ṣauma of Nisibis were commemorated together in the calendar of the Church of the East.

Fiey is unsure if there are one or two saints with this name. We preserve that uncertainty. There was one Dometius was a martyr was in a hermit's cave, and the other was a doctor fromKurdistanwho fave counsel to the emperor Valens. Both a martyr and a doctor by the name of Dometius are venerated in the area nearQilleth.

The legend of Romanus and Dometius was Coptic, but it exists in Syriac also. The author places the story in the time of Theodosius II. The two brothers were said to be sons of the Emperor Valentinian who go to Palestine to become monks.
Devotion to Saint Edna is widespread among Maronite Christians. Her name means "ear," and she is invoked for ear infections.

In hagiography: the “Egyptians ofQartmin” were a group of 800 monks fromEgyptwho were buried atQartmin. Their legend was connected to the crania in the monasteryQartmin. Eight hundred princes on pilgrimage fromEgyptbecame monks ofQartmin.
In hagiography: Elian was a third-century martyr fromEmesa. He was a doctor and was executed by his own father. The bishop Paul built a church in his honor.
In hagiography: Elijah was an ascetic commemorated by Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: Elijah was the bishop of ʿAyn Ward and the first bishop from the monastery of Simeon of Qartmin. He knew Theodute.

In hagiography: Elijah was the Syrian Orthodox bishop ofAntiochand a convert from the Melkite community. He was a monk from themonastery of Gubba Barraya. He was bishop ofApameaand later Patriarch ofAntioch. He was esteemed by Caliph Al-Walid I who allowed him to build a church.

In hagiography: Elijah ofḤirta(al-Hira) was a monastic founder from the sixth century. He was an Arab, a Lakhmid, who joined the monastery atMount Izlaand became a disciple of its founder, Abraham. He drove away corrupt monks. He leftMount Izlaand established a monastery nearMosul. He was widely venerated by the Arab Christians.
In hagiography: Elijah the Younger of Heliopolis was a martyr fromDamascus.
In hagiography: Elisha of Garbiya was a monk of Garbiya nearMidyat.
In hagiography: Elisha of Tanhir was commemorated by Rabban Saliba. Little is known about him nor about the location of Tanhir.

In hagiography: Acyndinus, Anempodistus, Pegasius, Aphtonius, and Elpidiphorus were Greek Christians who died during the reign of Shapur II, according to the legendary Acts describing their martyrdom.
In hagiography: See the East Syriac Patriarchs

In hagiography these children were the protagonists of a legend set in the time of the emperor Decius. Eight children ofEphesuswere placed in a cave with their dog Qitmir for 190 years. The legend dates to the middle of the fifth century.
Stephen (Esṭepanōs) was a martyr who was commemorated with Bassus andSusan
In hagiography: Stephen was a superior of a covenant. He was commemorated by Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: Eugenius and Macarius were priests and martyrs who were decapitated.
Eulogius was an ascetic who was a disciple of MarAwgin. He was either a servant of a lion or of a leper.
Eupraxia (Ewpraksiyā) and Olympias were martyrs.
In hagiography: Apollonius was a martyr with Eusebonia mentioned by Rabban Saliba.

In hagiography: Eutal (Awtal) was a disciple of Malke, son of Job of Ator, nearMosul. He was also known as "the Arab." He came to Malke for healing, and his tomb was at themonastery of Mar MalkeinṬur ʿAbdin.

In hagiography: Eutal of Magdala was a pagan who became a Christian in his youth. He abandoned his fiancée and became a monk with Mar Aba inMopsuestia. He was a miracle-worker who converted thousands of pagans.
In hagiography: Eutychios was a Mesopotamian martyr under Al-Walid. He was also known as “Eustathios,” and he died for refusing to convert to Islam.

In hagiography: Ezekiel was a monk who was born on the same day as the EmperorConstantine the Great. He was a Jew from the tribe of Manasseh who went toEgyptand became a disciple ofMar Awgin.Mar Awginand his disciples left for theregion of AdiabeneandBeth Garmai. They went toMaḥozeand baptized the entire city, after they healed the sick. Ezekiel went around the region converting the "Magians." He founded a monastery near Daduq. He ended his life inthe region of Kirkuk.

Febronia of Nisibis was a martyr and nun who lived in a convent nearNisibis. She was renown for her beauty, learning, asceticism, and bravery. She was martyred for refusing to marry a pagan statesman. She is venerated in the Syriac, Latin, and Greek traditions.
In hagiography: Gabriel of the superior monastery was cited with Mar Abraham as a founder of the superior monastery ofMosul.

Gabriel of Beth Qustan was from Beth Qustan and became Bishop of Qartmin. He fled marriage to become a monk. He was the superior of Qartmin and met the Caliph Ibn al-Hattab. He performed miracles and set out the measurements of the monastery of Qartmin. His body was exhumed to avoid an onslaught of the plague.
In hagiography: Gabriel ofKashkar, also called the "little man," was a monk who founded three monasteries nearMaḥoze, Dayr Qunni, and Husra.

In hagiography: Gabrona of Qarta was a Syriac monk under the patriarchSabrisho. He was fromBeth ʿArabaye. He healed the daughter of village leader, Shmona, and he constructed a monastery called Dayr al Qara.
In hagiography: Gamaliel and his son Habib were celebrated in the calendar of Rabban Saliba.

In hagiography: Ganni ofḤirtaor Rabban Haya was a monk fromBeth Aramaye. He sold everything he had and gave his possessions to the poor. He became a disciple of Mar Abraham onMount Izla.Simeon of Taybuthapraised his virtues, and this may have inspired the composition of the Liber Castitatis.

In hagiography: Diocletian fell in love with a young woman, Rhipsime, when he saw her picture. She lived a convent with 17 others, and they fled toArmenia. They were captured by the king Tiridates, who tortured and kills Rhipsime, her teacher Gayana, and the other virgins. In the hagiographical account, the king was then turned into a boar. After the king is cured, he andArmeniaconvert to Christianity.
In hagiography: George of the Greeks was probably called that in order to distinguish him from his predecessor.
In hagiography: George ofḤarranwas a bishop who came from the monastery ofQartmin. According to his life, during this time, there was much destruction, a flood, and a resurgence of paganism.

George ofIzlawas a monk and a convert from Zoroastrianism. His name was Mihrangusnap. He was noted for his conversations with the Monophysites and opposition to Gabriel of Sinjar, a convert from the Dyophysites to the Monophysites. Gabriel condemned George to shah Kusro for leaving his Zoroastrianism, and thus George of Izla was put to death.

In hagiography: Golinduch, the "living martyr," was a Persian princess who became a Christian through the influence of Greek prisoners of war. She was tortured and imprisoned for converting to Christianity, but she was freed by an angel and fled toNisibisandMabbug. She was venerated as a living martyr. Her life was preserved in Georgian.
In hagiography: Gregory or George, Zwanarse, and Yazdapanah were recent East Syriac martyrs.

Gregory Pīrānguŝnasp was a Zoroastrian Convert from the family of Mihran. He was imprisoned by the Byzantines and treated well by Justin I. He converted to Christianity. He was freed by a truce with Kusro, but his family put him to death in 542.
Gubarlāhā and his sister Qāzō were twins of Shapur II who were converted to Christianity through Dādū, a military officer from Medes. They were all put to death at Karka de Ledan.

In hagiography: Guhishtazad was a eunuch martyr atKarka d-Ledan. He was an old man who worked under Shapur II. He was head of the eunuchs and became a Christian, but he lapsed into Zoroastrianism. But the example ofSimeon bar Ṣabbaʿeinspired Guhishtazad to become Christian again, and he died a martyr.
In hagiography: Guhishtazad was a eunuch martyr fromKarka d-Beth Slokh.
Shmonaand Guria were two martyrs who were killed inEdessaduring the Diocletian persecution. There was great devotion to these saints in Edessa.

Habib was a deacon of the village of Telshaha near Edessa. He continued, despite the persecution that caused the death ofShmona and Guria, to travel from village to village encouraging the Christians. It was in the region of Zeugma on the Euphrates when he learned that Lysanius was looking for him. He was imprisoned and burnt to death, and his mother accompanied him to his death. He was entombed near Shmona and Guria.
In hagiography: Habib was a disciple ofJacob of Serugh.
This Habib, a son of Gamaliel, could be identified with John of Gamaliel, who was mentioned in the life of Samuel of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Habib ofScetiswas a monk who appears among a group of disciples ofMar Awgin. He may have become bishop ofTanaosorAthens.
Ḥananyā was a layman arrested in year six of the persecution of Shapur by order of the mobed Ardishag. He was martyred three times. There was a church dedicated to him in Erbil.
In hagiography: Ḥananya ofDayr al-Zaʿfaranwas a Syrian Orthodox bishop ofMardinandKfartuto. He built a monastery that was named after him on the ruins of the monastery of Slemun.

In hagiography: Helen, the mother ofConstantine the Great, is honored in the Syriac church in the hymn to the holy women. Her role in the discovery of the true cross was described in the Syriac narratives. Her feast day is with her son,Constantine.
In hagiography: Heliodorus was a bishop ofBeth Zabdai. 9000 inhabitants of his city were deported toPersia. Many of his community were later martyred, called the martyrs of .
In hagiography: Heraclas of Kafar Sama was a recluse from the village ofMidyat.
Ilarīyā (Hilaria) was the daughter of Zeno who fled to the desert to become a monk. She was known as John the Eunuch, and she performed many miracles.
In hagiography: Hananisho was a Catholicos of the Church of the East.
In hagiography: Hormizd was a martyr ofBeth Garmaiunder Yazdegerd. He had nine friends, and all were converts from Zoroastrianism or had Zoroastrian wives. They were tortured to death.

Rabban Hormizd was a monastic founder of the Church of the East who lived under the Patriarch Isho-yaw II. He spent 32 years at the monastery of Bar 'Idta, and then he and other monks left and founded an important monastery near Mosul, north of Alqosh.
In hagiography: Hudahwi lived at the time of the Caliph Muʿawiya. Shortly after the Muslim conquest, Hudahwi builtthe monastery of Beth Hale.

In hagiography: Hwara, son of Theodore lived in the fourth century. He met a monk, Mar Aḥa, who had been taken captive by a crypto-Christian soldier in the Persian army. Aḥa cured Hwara of being mute and in response Hwara became a monk. They established monasteries nearNisibis, where Hwara was the successor of Mar Aḥa.
In hagiography: Hwartha or Astina was a Persian martyr along with her sonAbai.
In hagiography: Ia was a woman among the martyrs ofBeth Zabdaiwho converted the wives of some of the Zoroastrians and were tortured and martyred.
In hagiography: Ignatius was the bishop ofMeliteneat the end of the tenth century. He built the convent of the Mother of God and a great church ofMelitenethere.
In hagiography: Isaac was the bishop ofKarka.

In hagiography: The patriarch Isaac became bishop ofḤarranby the protection of the governor of theal-Jazira, ʿAbd Allāh. Issac became Patriarch when ʿAbd Allāh becameCaliph Al-Mansur. But Al-Mansur had Patriarch Isaac killed and his body thrown into theEuphrates.

In hagiography: Isaac was a bishop ofEdessa. He was named with the approval of the Persians who occupied the city. He refused to give communion to Heraclius on account of the emperor's support of Chalcedon.

Isaiah of Aleppo was a saint said to be the last survivor of the disciples of MarAwgin, and some traditions attribute the composition of the life of Awgin to him. Isaiah and his wife never touched, living together in continence. He travelled throughout Mesopotamia and converted 3000 Marcionites.
In hagiography: Isaiah was an ascetic fromScetiswho founded a monastery inGaza. His life was written byZachariah the Rhetor. He was a friend of Peter the Egyptian.
In hagiography: Isodore was an abbot and the teacher ofMoses the Black.
In hagiography: Isidore was the bishop ofḤarran.

Īšōʿsawrān was a Zoroastrian Convert and later martyr fromErbil, whose life was written by Īšōʿyaw III ofAdiabene. His life speaks a great deal of the interactions between the Church of the East and Syrian Orthodox Church in the seventh century.
In hagiography: Ishoʿyahb became a monk ofMount Izla. According to legend, he founded a convent in a place where Kurds were supposed to have sacrifices to the demons. He healed many people.
In hagiography: Ishoʿyahb was a Catholicos.
In hagiography: Ishoʿyahb of Arzun was a Patriarch of the Church of the East.
In hagiography: Ishoʿyahb of Gdala was an East Syriac patriarch.

In hagiography: Ishoʿyahb bar Qusre was a monk from a monastery in the region ofAdiabene. He founded a church which becamethe church of Mar Ishaʿya. This became the residence of the metropolitan ofMosul.
In hagiography: Israel of Kashkar was the bishop ofKashkarand was later elected patriarch, but he was assassinated during the performance of the liturgy in 872.
In hagiography: Ithalaha was a deacon who was martyred with theBishop ʿAqewshmaduring the persecution of Shapur.
In hagiography: Ithalaha was the bishop fromEdessawho attended the Council of Nicaea. There are literary fragments attributed to him that survive in Armenian. He built the church ofCyrusandSaʿad.
In hagiography: Ithalaha was a pagan priest fromArbelawho became a Christian. He was imprisoned with other Persian martyrs, and his ear was cut off. He was decapitated atBeth Lapaṭ.
In hagiography: Jacob was a monk, visionary, and chanter fromBeth Garmai. He took over the leadership of a monastery founded by Ishoʿyahb which came to be named after Jacob.
In hagiography: Jacob was a disciple ofJacob Baradaeuswho became bishop ofthe monastery of Phesilta.

Jacob "the cut-up" was a noble Persian from the Royal City ofBeth Lapaṭ. He became a Christian, but he later abjured his Christian identity. His family reproached him, so he confessed his faith before Bahram V and was martyred.

Jacob the notary was of Greek origin, but he became the secretary for the Persian shah. He was forced into hard labor for refusing to abjure his Christian faith. He was cut up little by little, his fingers, hands, feet, and finally head. His relics were collected by Christians.
In hagiography: This Jacob the Recluse is mentioned as the founder of a monastery inSiirttogether withMar Hwisaat an unknown date.

Jacob the Recluse fled for the desert ofEgyptduring the persecution of the emperor Julian. He then headed to East toMesopotamiawith companions. They lived in a tower. Eventually he built a monastery atSalahinṬur ʿAbdin.

Jacob was a Priest of Beth Naggare nearAdiabenewho was martyred with the deaconAzadduring the persecution of Shapur II. The executioner washed his bloody sword in a pool, and the blood desiccated the pool.
Jacob the priest and his sisterMarywere martyrs from the village of Tell Salila during the reign of Shapur. Mary was martyred atTel Dara.
In hagiography: John was a Syriac doctor.

In hagiography: John, the son of a joiner, was a Persian Martyr who was killed by his ownfather. John was tortured with various metallic instruments, and he was ultimately decapitated. Hissisterwas also killed. His relics were collected byBar Hebraeus.
In hagiography: John III (Hovhannes) ofOdzounwas commemorated as a philosopher and Armenian catholicos.

In hagiography: John Bar ʿAbdun was Patriarch of the Syrian Orthodox church, and he had a life fraught with difficulty. He was accused of attracting Chalcedonians to the Syrian Orthodox, and he was brought toConstantinopleto be condemned by the Chalcedonians. He was slapped in thechurch of Hagia Sophiaby the Melkite Bishop John ofMelitene. He died in exile inThraceand was honored as a martyr by the Syrian Orthodox.

In hagiography: John the Arab was a monk who originally was from a rich family inḤirta. He studied atNisibis, went toMount Sinjar, and became a shepherd. He found a place onMount Izla, and he performed many miracles. Many fought over his relics after his death, and amonasterywas built over his remains near themonastery of Mar Awgin.
John the Almsgiver was a Melkite patriarch ofAlexandriawho was celebrated for his generosity to the poor. His life was also translated into Syriac. He had a wife and two children.
In hagiography: John the Blue was the bishop ofḤirta. He was also known as the young man fromḤirta.
In hagiography there is mention of a monastery nearQaraqoshnamed after this John Busnaya.

In hagiography: John the Egyptian or the mourner was the student and compatriot ofMar Awgin. He lived as a solitary onMount Qardu. He converted the pagans there. He built and was buried at a monastery calledḤlahlaḥwhich was renamed after him.

In hagiography: John the Camel-Driver was commemorated inThomas of Marga'sBook of Governors. In this account, Maran Zha, bishop ofḤaditaon theTigris, heard a camel driver singing Syriac chants among the Arab camel drivers. This man, John, had been a Syriac bishop of the Egyptian diaspora before he was captured by the Bedouins. He was entombed nearḤadita, but only his habit was found.
In hagiography: John ofḤarranwas commemorated as one of fifty miaphysite bishops exiled underJustin Iin 518.
In hagiography: According toBarsoum, this martyr, John ofKafar Sania, died underMaximinus Hercules.

In hagiography: John ofKamulwas born to a pagan family, from a royal Sasanian line. He was converted and tried to convinceShapurhis cousin not to persecute Christians.Mar Awginbaptized him under the name of John. He lived in a cave nearMount Gudiand performed many miracles. Themonastery of John of KamulinGazartabears his name.
In hagiography: John ofKashkarwas born in the region ofKashkar. After a series of abductions, he returned to themonastery of ʿAyn Deqla.
In hagiography: John of Kfone (al-Kfani) was a disciple ofMar Awgin. Themonasteryof this monk was found south ofZazinṬur ʿAbdin.
In hagiography: John Psaltes was mentioned in theLife of Rabban Samuel of Qartmin. A vision revealed to him the presence of relics in the place calledḤrbat Tuta.
In hagiography: John of Qartmin or John of Beth Sbirino was a noted paleograph who reestablished the use of estrangelo writing.

John the solitary was a monk ofṬur ʿAbdin. He might be John, the perfect Nazarite, whomJohn of Ephesusmentions. He was a monk from Zuqnin near Amida. He was forced to leave his cave on account of Chalcedonian aggression.

In hagiography: John was a priest fromEdessawho nourished 12 holy men in a cave. He became friends with Paul, his workman, who was actually a bishop in disguise. The two lived a life of prayer and spiritual companionship. They travelled toSinai. Back inEdessa, they interacted withMatthew the eunuch, a woman hiding in a monastery. They travelled toJerusalem. Paul performed miracles and fled toNisibis. John found him there, and Paul told him to return toEdessa. Paul died, and John died 8 months later. The story was set in the time of theBishop Rabbula of Edessa.
Jacob, the zealot priest, was arrested withYuḥanān bar Maryam(John), Bishop ofArbela, during the time of Shapur. They were decapitated atBeth Lapaṭ.
Yuḥanān bar Maryam (John) was the Bishop ofArbelawho was arrested withJacob the zealot. They were sent to Shapur, flogged, and decapitated.
In hagiography: Job ofAdiabenewas a doctor of the Syriac church.
In hagiography: Joseph was a disciple ofNarsai. They were martyrs ofBeth Garmai.
In hagiography: Joseph was the patriarch ofAntioch.
In hagiography: Joseph was a priest and martyr ofArbela.
Juliana was a companion of St.Barbara.
Yōlyānā (Julian) was the patriarch ofAntioch. He was a monk ofQenneshrin. He wrote against Sergius of Armenia.
Yōlēṭā (Julietta) was the mother ofCyriacus.
Cyprian and (Yusṭā) Justina were martyrs under Diocletian.
In hagiography: Karag is an abbot who figures in a Syrian orthodox calendar ofQaraqosh.
In hagiography: Karkus was commemorated as the successor ofIgnatiusinAntioch, and he was the fourth bishop of the city.
In hagiography: This could be Conon, the bishop ofTarsus, perhaps consecrated byJacob Baradaeusin 543.
In hagiography: Kurbur was a Roman magistrate and later a martyr who appeared in the passion ofSaint Eleutherios.
In hagiography: Labbe is often identified with the biblical Apostle Thaddeus.
Loranṭyos (Laurence) and Agrippa were companions and martyrs under Diocletian. Agrippa was a prefect of Syria who had converted to the faith in Mesopotamia.
In hagiography: Lazarus was a confessor, a victim ofBarsauma of Nisibis. He was also a disciple ofSamuel of Qartmin.
Leontius of Tripoli was a martyr. He had been a Roman solider. There was a monastery named after him in which Severus of Antioch was baptized.
Longinus was an asecetic and a martyr with Bassus andSusan, converts from Zoroastrianism whom Longinus baptized.

In hagiography: Luke was commemorated as a deacon under theBishop Polychronus. He was decapitated withParmenius,Helimenas, andChrysostelus, and another deacon,Mucius, under the emperorGaleriusin a place calledCordula (Qardu?).
In hagiography: Macarius was a priest and martyr with Eugene.
Māqārīs of Alexandria who came into the Syriac tradition viaʿEnanishoʿ'sSyriac translation of the Paradise of the FathersbyPalladius.
Ṣulṭan Mahduk was a martyr of Tur Berʿain who was commemorated with her brothers Adorparma and Mirnarsai.

Maʿin was a general of Shapur II. He became a Christian when he witnesses the martyrdom ofDōdō. He was baptized and arrested. He built 69 places of worship aroundSinjar. He died at age 114 in a monastery that he built nearEuropos.

Mar Malke was a monk whose story overlaps with MarAwgin. He was the son of Awgin's sister, Rebecca. He was from Clysma. He gave to the poor and joined his uncle on Mt Izla. He built a monastery near Ankah near Midyat. He performed miracles and journeyed to Jerusalem.
In hagiography: Malus was a martyr who could be the same as Miles, bishop of Susa.
Mama was a martyr of Beth Sloth.
In hagiography: Mamelhta was a virgin and martyr fromBeth Garmai. She was known in the Greek martyr Acts as Mamlaha, Mamlahtina, Mazahia or Malpetha.
Maʿna was in the circle of martyrs withSapor, Bishop of Niqatorwhich also includedSimeon,Abraham,Isaacduring the persecution ofYazdgerd II.
In hagiography: Mark was a solitary ascetic known from thelife of Macariusin theParadise of the FathersbyPalladius. He was distinguished by his wrestling with the temptations of the flesh.
Mark of Tarmuqa was a solitary Athenian inEthiopia. Serapion visited him at the Mountain of Tarmuqa.
Mari was the apostle to Mesopotamia. He was ordained byAddaito establish Christian communities in the royal cities of the Parthians.
In hagiography: Mari of Beth Sahde was mentioned two times by Rabban Saliba.

In hagiography: Mari and his wifeMarthawere Roman martyrs. Husband and wife, they went toRomeon a pilgrimage with their children,AudifaxandAbaq, and they were taken in the persecution ofCladius II. Mari and his two sons were decapitated and Martha was drowned.
In hagiography: Mary was one of daughters of the covenant who was martyred withTheclainAdiabene.
In hagiography: Mary was the sister ofPanteleon (Batala)and was commemorated with him.
In hagiography: Mary was commorated as a martyr. She and her brother the priestJacobwere from the village ofTell Salila. She was martyred atTel DaraunderShapur.
While some hagiographical sources placeMar Awginin the company of his two sisters,TheclaandStratonike, Rabban Saliba includes Mary ofScetisin the company of the father of the monks.

After her mother died, Marina entered the monastery with her father. She disguised herself as a man, Marinos. A woman blamed her for her pregnancy, and she was expelled from the monastery. She miraculously nursed the baby. Her sex was discovered after her death. Among the Syrians, she was venerated by the Maronites.
In hagiography: Maron was an anchorite.
In hagiography: Maron ofʿAyn Wardwas a superior of the monastery ofQartminand was mentioned in the life ofSamuel of Qartmin. He baptized 2000 people inMesopotamia.

In hagiography: Martha was commorated for being martyred inRomewith her husband,Mari, and children,AudifaxandAbaq, while they were on a pilgrimage. They were taken in the persecution ofCladius II. Mari and his two sons were decapitated and Martha was drowned.

Martha was a Virgin Martyr and the daughter ofPosi. They were Greeks deported to the Sasanian empire. They were martyred at Karka d-Ledan. Her throat was cut like a young lamb on the day of Easter, 340.
In hagiography: Martha was one of daughters of the covenant who was martyred withTheclainAdiabene.
In hagiography: Mattai (Matta) was born nearAmida. He had a marvelous youth and became a monk. A persecution caused him to flee to theMountain of Alpep, northwest ofMosul.
In hagiography: Maura and her husbandTimothywere Egyptian martyrs. They were killed for refusing to burn their copies of Christian scripture.
In hagiography:Maximusand Dometius were brother martyrs. They were brothers, the sons ofValentinian, who fled their father's palace to become monks inPalestine. They went toEgyptand metMacarius.
In hagiography: Metkarkana the Vagabond was commemorated in the Maronite calendar.

In hagiography: Michael the Companion of Angels was a monk linked toMar Awgin. In some traditions, he was the hagiographer of theLife of Awgin. He was commemorated with other monastic founders inMesopotamia.
In hagiography: Michael of Tarʿil was commemorated as a disciple ofSabrishoʿ d-Beth Qoqa. He was commemorated at the eponymous monastery ofMar Mikhaʾil of Tarʿilin the region ofAdiabene.
In hagiography: Michael and his sister (Shiris?) were martyred outside the gate ofMardin in a place called theMonastery of the Fishor theMonastery of the Column.
Mikhā of Nuhadra was the founder of a monastery or a church in the village of Alqosh, north of Mosul.
In hagiography: Mihrnarsai, his sisterSultan Mahduk, and their brotherAdorparmawere among the martyrs ofTur Berʿain.
Mihrsapor was a convert from Zoroastrianism who was imprisoned and died of hunger and thirst.

The wonder-working monkDaniel the Doctor, a disciple of MarAwgin, also healed the son of the governor of Tel Ḥesh, Miles. Miles was consecrated Bishop of Tel Ḥesh and was stoned to death under Shapur.
Moses of Beth Sayyare helped to restore the monastery ofBeth Sayyarewhich was founded byMar Abraham, a disciple ofMar Awgin.

In hagiography: Moses the Black (or Moses the Thief) was instructed and baptized byMacarius. He was a man of great physical and spiritual strength who performed many miracles and overcame adversity. He was killed by Bedouins who attacked hismonastery.
In hagiography: Mqadashta (or The Sanctified) was a sister ofTarboandCatholicos Simeon bar Sabbaʿe.
In hagiography: Muʿawiya was a martyr inArabiawho was thrown to the beasts.
In hagiography: Munyatos was a saint in the Maronite calendar.
In hagiography: The martyrs ofNagran, led byArethas, died inḤimyar, condemned byJoseph, a Jewish governor.
In hagiography: Narsai, bishop ofSharqart, andJosephhis disciple, were martyrs ofBeth Garmai.
Narsai was a monk and martyr. He was decapitated.
In hagiography: Nestorius ofConstantinoplewas a doctor of the Church of the East.
In hagiography: Nicholas figures in the Maronite calendar.
In Syriac hagiography, there is an attested saint named Nuhra. It may be that this name, Syriac for "light," is a translation of the Greek "Phocas" or the Latin "Lumen."
Alūmpiyā (Olympias) was a deaconess of Constantinople.

Onesima was the daughter of a king and hermit inEgypt. She was mentioned in the hymns on the holy women and many liturgical pieces. She fled her royal house to become a hermit with 40 other nuns, and she feigned madness.
Pantaleon (Panṭalēʾōn) was a doctor and a martyr. He was also known as Butlana, Butlan, and Batala. He converted to Christianity and cured many people. He was martyred under Diocletian.
In hagiography: Papa was a bishop ofArzun.
In hagiography: Papa was a early patriarch of the Church of the East.
In hagiography: Paul was bishop ofEdessa. He translated the hymns ofSeverusand revised a Syriac translation of Gregory.

In hagiography: Paul of Nisibis was originally fromPrat Maysan. He was a disciple ofMar Aba Iwho signed the synod of Joseph in 554. He was an intermediary betweenKhusroandJustinianandJustin II. He debated also withHenana of Adiabeneover theology of the Church of the East.

John was a priest fromEdessawho nourished 12 holy men in a cave. He became friends with Paul, his workman, who was actually a Bishop in disguise. The two lived a life of prayer and spiritual companionship. They travelled toSinai. Back in Edessa, they interacted with Matthew the eunuch, a woman hiding in a monastery. They travelled toJerusalem. Paul performed miracles and fled toNisibis. John found him there, and Paul told him to return to Edessa. Paul died, and John died 8 months later. The story was set in the time of the BishopRabbula.
In hagiography: Paul the interpreter commented on the Psalms. He might be Paul of Nisibis or Paul of Tella.
In hagiography: Peroz ofBeth Lapatwas a high born Zoroastrian who became a Christian and was martyred beforeBahram V.
Pethiyōn, a patriarch, was a man of virtue who formed a favorable relationship with a Muslim governor, Halid al Qasri, whose mother was a Christian.

In hagiography: Pethion was a Zoroastrian convert who, with his uncle the monkYazdin, preached inthe region of the lower Zab. His hagiography was connected to that of an aristocratic father and daughter pair whom he helped to convert:Adorhormizdand his daughterAnahid. Pethion was martyred underYazdegerd II.
In hagiography: Pethion was a monk and a founder of aconventnorth of theGreater Zab.
In hagiography: Pharkia was a scribe mentioned by Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: Peter ofAlexandriawas the seventeenth bishop ofAntioch. He was martyred under the emperorMaximinus.
In hagiography: Peter of Antioch was patriarch ofAntiochand reinforced the connections of his church withAlexandria. He fought against "heresies" ofDamian of Alexandria.
Mar Pinḥas was a martyr from the fourth century. He was from Qardu, and he was a disciple of MarAwgin.
In hagiography: Plato (or Platon) is known through theActs of Platowhich exist in Greek, Latin and Armenian. He was a bishop ofAncyraand a martyr underMaximinus.
In hagiography: Polychronus was a bishop and a martyr. He was probably a deported Greek who became bishop ofBabylonia.
Pōsi and his daughterMarthawere Greeks deported to the Sasanian empire. They were martyred at Karka d-Ledan. Pōsi had been chief of the royal artisans.

In hagiography: Protonike was purportedly the wife of the emperorClaudius. Her legend was interpolated intoThe Teaching of Addai. She travelled toJerusalem, converted to Christianity, and discovered the true cross.
Qardag was a military saint and a martyr. He was a convert from a high-born Zoroastrian family. His cult was localized north of Arbela.
In hagiography: Qashish ofḤaḥwas a monk mentioned inJohn of Ephesus'Lives of the Eastern Saints. He went on pilgrimages and helpedthe Empress Theodorato build a hostel for the Miaphysites.
In hagiography: Qawma was a monk and dendrite saint fromBeth Garmai. His body did not decay.
In hagiography: Qayyuma of Baz was a monk. He evangelized theregion of BaznearHakkari.
In hagiography: Quna (or Conon or Yona) was the bishop ofEdessa. He set the foundations for thenew cathedralofEdessawhich was finished by his succesorSaʿad.

In hagiography: Diocletian fell in love with a young woman, Rhipsime, when he saw her picture. She lived a convent with 17 others, and they fled to Armenia. They were captured by the king Tiridates, who tortured and killed Rhipsime, her teacher Gayana, and the other virgins. Tiridates was turned into a boar. Gregory cured the king, and Armenia converted to Christianity.
In hagiography: Blessed Rifqa Rayyis was a Maronite nun. She was a blind mystic.

In hagiography: Risha (or Alexius) was also known as the man of God of Edessa. He was born a rich man, but he lived as a beggar inEdessa. He gave all that he had to the poor. He lived at the time ofBishop Rabbula of Edessa.
Rōmānōs was a deacon and a martyr from Caesarea Palestine. He died in the persecution of Diocletian.
In hagiography: Ruben was a monk and perhaps a stylite ofQartmin.
Rūbēl was an ascetic warrior from Thrace who became a leader of a monastery of 35 monks. He lived near Nisibis and his life was dated to the time of Trajan.
In hagiography: Ruhana the Melodist was identified withCyriacus, disciple ofEuthymiainPalestine.
In hagiography: Saʿad (or Saʿdu) was bishop ofEdessaand finished the cathederal begun byQuna.
In hagiography: Saba Gushnazdad was a monk fromBeth Lashpar. He was a Zoroastrian convert who became a monk and converted many Kurds.
Sābā Pirgushnasp was a child martyr. He was the child of the governor of Beth ʿArabaye. He was martyred under Shapur II at the age of 12.
In hagiography: Sabbatius was a solitary monk who lived near the banks of theEuphrates.
In hagiography: Sabellius andShapirawere the parents of the martyr,Talia. They conceived him when they were at the age of 52 years.
In hagiography: Shabra was a child saint commemorated nearMidyat.
In hagiography: Shahdost was a Catholicos and a Persian Martyr. He was the successor ofSimeon Bar Sabbaʿe.
In hagiography: The saints of themonastery of Mar Abhaiwere commemorated by Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: See John Psaltes.
In hagiography: Shallitha was a common name that means "governor." This may refer toArtemios, the governor ofEgyptunder the emperorJulian.

In hagiography: Samuel of Qartmin was fromEshtinnearMardin. He founded the monastery ofQartmin, with the help of an angel who delineated it for him. His disciple wasSimeon of Qartmin. He performed numerous miracles; he brought an end to a plague overḤaḥ.
In hagiography: Sanatruq was a frozen martyr in the time ofJulianand a companion ofBrihisho.
In hagiography: Shapira was the wife ofSabelliusand the mother ofTalia.
In hagiography: Shapor was a frozen martyr in the time of Julian and a companion ofBrihisho.
In hagiography: Shapur (Šapor) was a bishop of Niqator who was martyred under Shapur II with Isaac, Maʿna, and Abraham.

In hagiography: “Sarah” was the traditional name for a male martyr’s sister. This pseudonymous usage is derived fromSarahthe biblical matriarch and wife ofAbraham. One of the most prominent women named "Sarah" in Syriac hagiography wasSarathe sister ofBehnam. Another is theSarahassociated withZayna.
In hagiography: Sarah, see also Zayna.
In hagiography: Sharbil became a monk and hermit of the monasteries ofQozhaza,Mayfuq, andKififane. He lived as a hermit inʿAnnanyaand performed many miracles.

Sharbel and his sister Babai were martyrs ofEdessa. Sharbel had been a pagan priest, but he converted to Christianity. He was martyred under Trajan. Sharbel and Babai were contemporary with the priestBarsamya.

In hagiography: Sasin was a bishop and a martyr. He was bishop ofCyzicus. He was beaten and tortured, but then he was freed with the accession ofConstantine the Great. He attended the Council of Nicaea but was later martyred underConstantius.

In hagiography: Sawrisho was a student of theSchool of Nisibis. He became a monk ofMount Qarduand performed many miracles. He became a bishop and played a role in the conversion ofAl Numan, the Lakhmid phylarch. Under the influence ofKhusro II, he became the Catholicos of the Church of the East.
In hagiography: Sawrisho was a monk who founded themonastery of the martyrsnearTagrit. These monks took refuge in a village during the Muslim conquest.
In hagiography: For Šaʿya, please see Isaiah of Aleppo.
In hagiography: Shayna was identified as "Abramios of Antioch", a converted Jewish thief fromAntioch.
In hagiography: Seleucus, see Stratonike.
In hagiography: Sergius was a deacon ofHuzri. He may have been a writer.
In hagiography: Sergius ofTellawas the successor ofJacob Baradaeus. He accompanied his teacher toConstantinoplewhere he was received bythe Empress Theodora.

In hagiography: Sergius ofthe Barren Mountain (Jebel Butman/al-Jabal al-Qāḥil)was a monk who founded a monastery known as theSuspended Monastery (Dayr al-Muʿallaq).It became the residence of the bishops ofBalad.
In hagiography: Sergius of Zuqnin, was a monk at the monastery ofZuqninand may also be the same Sergius elsewhere identified asSergius ofQenneshrin .

Sergius was one of the most popular saints of the Orient. He was a Roman soldier martyred shortly after his friendBacchussince he refused to sacrifice to the Roman gods. Sergius was decapitated atResafaon theEuphrates.

In hagiography: Severus, bishop ofSamosataand known as a wonder-worker, was the brother of the PatriarchAthanasius the Camel-Driver. He accompanied his brother to meetHeracliusto return the cross ofJerusalem, and he endured persecution for his Miaphysite position. He lived much of the year as a solitary monk, and he was lame for much of his life after he broke his leg from falling off a horse. He was known for chasing away demons.
In hagiography: Severus ofKafar Zewas the superior of the monastery ofQartminand was mentioned in theLife of Rabban Samuel of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Severus the Mathematician was an astronomer fromNisibiswho became bishop ofQenneshrinin 630.
In hagiography: Silvanus of Edessa was the 26th bishop ofEdessa.
Simeon, commemorated on August 12, was fromEdessa. He was a monk who went toSamosataon the Euphrates. He shared his cave with an anchorite called Elie and performed many miracles.
In hagiography: Simeon was a bishop ofEdessa, and was succeeded byGabriel, bishop of Edessa.

Simeon was the Bishop ofḤarran. He was also known as “Simeon of the Olives.” He was born inṬur ʿAbdinand had been a student in the monastery ofQartmin. He was a great builder of churches and monasteries, and assisted Muslims inNisibisby helping them build a mosque.
In hagiography: Simeon was a contemporary ofShapor, bishop ofNiqator and was martyred with the bishop and several others (Abraham,IsaacandMaʿna) during the persecution ofYazdgerd II.

Simeon was known as the second founder of the monastery of Qartmin orMor Gabriel. He was healed at a young age by Samuel of Qartmin, who also instructed him in monasticism. An angel led them to the place where they were to construct the monastery of Qartmin. He was the second abbot of Qartmin and blessedRabbulaof Edessa.
In hagiography: Simeon may have been the bishop ofDarawho participated in the synod ofMantzikertthat sealed union with the Armenian church underJohn III the Philosopher.
In hagiography: Simeon ofPapo (of Fafo)was a superior ofQartminmentioned in theLife of Rabban Samuel of Qartmin. He opened the eyes of a blind man before the shahKhusro.
In hagiography: Simeon the Greek was a monk mentioned in theLife of Rabban Samuel of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Simeon of the Sea was a monk who performed miracles in the sea. He might be the Saint Simeon for whom the opening of theOronteswas named.
In hagiography: Simeon ofOigonais an otherwise unattested saint of the fifteenth century.
In hagiography: Simeon was commemorated as the builder of theQarqaphto (The Skull) Monastery, betweenReshʿaynaandMagdalin thehigh Gazira.
In hagiography: Simeon the Stylite, the younger was fromAntioch, the child ofJohnandMartha. He showed signs of holiness already as an infant. He lived on a column on theWonderful Mountain.

In hagiography: Shirin and her two children were martyrs fromBeth Zadoq. She was baking bread when she learned of 12000 martyrs underYazdegerd II. She took herself and her children before the governor and confessed her Christian faith to him. She and her children were decapitated.

In hagiography: Shirin was born inKarka d-Beth Slokhto a Zoroastrian family but converted to Christianity. She faced great hardship from her family on account of this. She was imprisoned and executed.

In hagiography: Shlemun the Mourner was bishop ofḤaditaon theTigristowards the middle of the VIII century. He converted Muslims for which he was beaten and made to shave his beard and head. He had a rivalry withʿIsa ibn Shahlupa, the head of doctors of the caliph, concerning taxes imposed on Christians by Muslim authorities. He opposed the election ofCatholicos Timothy Iin 780. He died at themonastery of Mar AhrunnearBalad.
In hagiography: Shmona was a martyr fromEdessawho was mentioned in theActs of the Edessa MartyrswithGuria.

In hagiography: Shenoute ofAtripewas a miaphysite Egyptian monk and a superior of theWhite Monastery. He enforced a strict interpretation of the rule ofPachomius. He often left his monastery to fight pagans and heretics. There was a Syriac version of his life.
In hagiography: Sophenian was from the region south ofArmeniabetween theTigrisand theEuphrates. He was a superior of the monastery ofQartmin.
Sophie or "wisdom" with her three daughters,Faith,Hope, andCharity, were martyred in Rome under Hadrian. Sophie was invoked as a saint to fight malaria.
In hagiography: Stratonike was the sister ofMar AwginandThecla. She was mentioned in theHymns on the Holy Women.

Stratonike, her husband Seleucus, and their companions were martyrs from Cyziqus on the Sea of Marmara. Martyred under Maximinus, Stratonike was honored in the Hymns on the Holy Women, among the "martyrs of the East and West."

In hagiography: Bassus and his twin Suzanna were twin children of a Zoroastrian governor. They were informed about Christianity by a Christian slave. They were baptized by an ascetic named Longinus. They were killed by their father. At least onemonastery commemorating Mar Bassuswas founded nearApamea.

Ṭahmazgerd was an executioner who was converted upon seeing the example of the martyrs ofKirkuk, including Shirin and her children. He was crucified upside down. There is a church ofMar Ṭahmasgardwithin Kirkuk.

Talia was the child of Sabellius and Shapira, who had him at the age of 52. A revelation predicted that Talia, at age two, would kill impious kings. This news reached the ears of the governor, and they were all arrested. The child was tried and tortured multiple times, and his parents were stoned. He was cut in many pieces, but still found intact. He was finally killed after many ordeals, and his example converted people. He was a martyr at age two. A shrine atRomaniyawas built to him.

After the execution ofSimeon Bar Sabbaʿe, the wife of Shapur became sick. People accused the sister of Simeon, Tarbo, of witchcraft that caused the queen's sickness. Tarbo and her servant were arrested. They were tortured and cut into many pieces.
Ṭāṭāq Dōmasṭīqa was the chamberlain of Yazdegerd I. He was fromAdiabene. He was decapitated.
Thecla or Taqla and her companions, including Mary, were daughters of the covenant. They were arrested, interrogated, and martyred.
In hagiography: Mar Theodore is an otherwise unattested saint mentioned in theCalendar of Qaraqosand by Rabban Saliba.

In hagiography: Theodore of Kashkar was a monk who founded his own school outside ofKashkar. When he was older, he retired in solitude and grew wild herbs. He went to theCaliph Umar I ibn al-Hattabto obtain an exemption for priests and deacons.
In hagiography: Theodosius was a bishop, perhaps a monk fromQartmin, who died in an oven along with those who were martyred with him.
In hagiography: Thomas was a bishop and confessor, an otherwise unattested saint mentioned by Rabban Saliba.
In hagiography: Thomas of Ḥarran was a bishop ofḤarranand a disciple ofSimeon of the Olives.
In hagiography: Thomas was a stylite saint ofTella.
In hagiography: Thuthael was a martyr ofEdessawho was commemorated withSharbel.
In hagiography: Thuthael was a stylite and disciple ofSamuel of Qartmin.
In hagiography: Timothy was the bishop ofEdessa. He participated in a synod inMabbugthat electedthe deacon George.

In hagiography: Timothy ofAlexandria, also known as Aelurus or "the Cat", was the miaphysite patriarch ofAlexandria. He was exiled in 460 but reclaimed his see in 475. He was active in fighting against the Council of Chalcedon.
The priestDanieland his sister Wardē from Raziq (nearTehran) were arrested two years afterMiles; they were dismembered.

Yareth was a monk who was trained in the monastery of Pachomius and then later joined the monks of the circle of MarAwginon MountIzla. He visited the monastery ofMar Ahha, near where the ark of the covenant of Moses was. He converted the region ofBeth Zabdai. There he built a monastery and lived with his disciple Quryaqos.
In hagiography: Rabban Jonah (Yawnan) was a famous monk of the monastery ofBar Ṭura.

In hagiography: Jonah of Anbar (Yawnān Nūkhriṭā/the "Foreigner") was bornYuwanisin a noble family of the lineage ofConstantine the Great. He became a disciple ofMar Awgin. He changed his name to Jonah. He journeyed toJerusalemandScetis.Mar Awginsent him to theland of the Persians, and he foundedthe monastery at Peroz Shapuron theEuphrates.
Yawnan andBrihisowere two priests from Beth Asa. Yawnan and his brother went to prison during a persecution to encourage future martyrs. Later they were also arrested and martyred.
In hagiography: Jonah of Ḥaḥ was a bishop ofḤaḥ.
In hagiography: Yazdanduht was a holy woman ofArbelawho, in 345, in the royal cities, took care of and buried 120 martyrs ofAdiabene(111 priests and deacons; nine virgins).
In hagiography: Yazdapnah was the bishop ofKashkar. He was a contemporary of thePatriarch Mar Emmeh (646-49)andRabban Theodore.
In hagiography: Yazdapnah was a martyr with Gregory.

Yazdapnah was a magian from a village nearKarka de LedaninBeth Huzaye(Huzistan). He stayed five years in prison before the martyrdom ofGregory Pirangusnasp. He was decapitated. Another confessor, Awida, followed Yazdapnah. They cut off Awida's nose and ear.

Yazdbozid or Theodute was a Zoroastrian Convert. He was brought to Christianity by the martyrdom ofGregory Pīrānguŝnasp. He was martyred in 553 under Chosroes Anosirwan. The original Syriac of his hagiography text was lost, but it was preserved in Georgian and Armenian.

In hagiography: Yazdin was an anchorite from the fifth century. He converted to Christianity along with his brother,Dadisho. Dadisho's son,Pethion, became a martyr and convertedAdorhormizdand his daughterAnahid.
In hagiography: Christine or Yazdoi fromKarka d-Beth Slokhwas the daughter of a Zoroastrian governor who was martyred after her marriage.

In hagiography: Yozadaq was a monk and a disciple ofRabban Bar ʿIdtaand a companion ofRabban HormizdonMount Resa. He built a monastery. He wrote letters including one thanking one of his disciples for a copy of the works ofIsaac of Nineveh.

In hagiography: Zakka was probably a disciple ofMar Mattai, and thus he was connected with the saints ofMosul. Before becoming the successor ofMar Mattai, he inhabited a small cell at the end ofthe valley of Mar Abrahamwhich later became a Yezidi shrine. He was also connected with the legend ofBehnam.

Zaʿūra was an anchorite whose life was memorialized byJohn of Ephesus. He was a stylite saint who famously replaced his teacher, another stylite, when the former was ready to retire. Zaʿūra also travelled toConstantinoplein order to advocate for the cause of the Miaphysites before the EmpressTheodora.

Zayʿa was one of the most popular saints in the Chaldean and Assyrian villages. He was a Palestinian and was a missionary to northern Iraq, along with his disciple Tabor. He lived forty years in a cave of Mount Gara.

In hagiography: Zayna, a bishop and martyr, and his sisterSarah, were a brother and sister pair similar toBehnamandSara. Their cult inTagritwas a rival to that ofBehnamandSaraatMar Mattai. Zayna was the son ofAtor, a king. He became a monk and bishop. Their story was elaborate and involved dragons, healed kings, profitable caravans, and supernatural senses. The cult of Zayna and Sarah was very popular inQaraqosh.
